Topic.Title: been investing and trading for over 30 years

Message.Msg: IMHO, technically BAC is due for a pullback to the 12's It's recent run up has been on relatively low volume. While the last few down days has been on relatively higher volume which is a negative. With the lawsuit hearings going on it's - in my opinion - time to sit on the sidelines with regards to BAC or just day-trade it for 5-20 cent increments. If you want to "gamble" in either direction buy weekly puts or calls. Don't get me wrong, if they clear up the lawsuit in their favor BAC should move higher in relatively short-order. If they lose, who knows. Bottomline, it's all about risk / reward (in the short-term) and the risk of being long overnight at the moment is too great for me.

Message.Title: Life of A Day Trader
Message.Msg: Don't know about you guys but I wake up very early in the morning like around 3:AM or so. Run 5 miles around the park. Come back. Took a shower. Drink like about 10 beers. Smoke some weed and then sign on to Ameritrade. That's when the action begins. Put about 700 bucks in this casino. Put another 2000 bucks in that casino. Then I go to the coffee house to sweet talk with all the girls. Normally I never say anything about stocks. Just music and fashion and sex. Off course I never forgot to bad mouth Obama for a little bit. Then I come back to my little bunker. Look at my streamer for a little bit then take a nap. Wake up and sell all my holdings at around 11:AM. Someday I make enough monies to pay the rent and could afford a lobster. Someday I end up eating peanut butter all night. And the next day the same routine begins.

Message.Title: Senators Crafting Bill To Compensate FNMA Common Shareholders!!!
Message.Msg: According to the report, Senators Corker and Warner would see Fannie and Freddie liquidated within five years, with the U.S. Treasury taking over GSE mortgage guarantees, and "liquidation first would go to the U.S. government as the senior preferred shareholder in each of the companies, and then to holders of junior preferred shares, followed by holders of the common shares." Topic.Title: Bankruptcy for Countrywide

Message.Msg: Actually, the bankruptcy comment had to do with what would have happened if BAC hadn't bought Countrywide. The thought process was that BAC had limited successor liability. There is still an open question whether BAC could put Countrywide in bankruptcy and if they did, how that would affect their liability. These particular issues have yet to be clearly determined in court. A bankruptcy of Countrywide would be very messy and involve many years of court action which I think BAC has wanted to avoid.

Message.Title: Emails of top Obama appointees using secret Email accounts. Just more of Obama's fascist governance
Message.Msg: The scope of using the secret accounts across government remains a mystery: Most U.S. agencies have failed to turn over lists of political appointees' email addresses, which the AP sought under the Freedom of Information Act more than three months ago. The Labor Department initially asked the AP to pay more than $1 million for its email addresses.The secret email accounts complicate an agency's legal responsibilities to find and turn over emails in response to congressional or internal investigations, civil lawsuits or public records requests because employees assigned to compile such responses would necessarily need to know about the accounts to search them. Secret accounts also drive perceptions that government officials are trying to hide actions or decisions. This is the crappiest most bottom dwelling anti-American administration in history.

Topic.Title: BAC will be approved .Judge did not postpone as AIG requested in order to build their case for their objection to $8.5bl settlement.

Message.Msg: I wouldn't read too much into that. While I agree that the judge will most likely rule for BAC, postponement is a very common tactic. It is one of the most common requests made in court.

Topic.Title: Senators Crafting Bill To Compensate FNMA Common Shareholders!!!

Message.Msg: All I see is that they are simply going according to standard practice of hierarchy of compensation. This doesn't mean common shareholders will see anything. It is just setting the order of precedence of who will be compensated first from whatever funds are received through liquidation. If enough is left over after all other claimants are satisfied, then common shareholders will divide it up.

Message.Title: MBS trustees not subject to Trust Indenture Act
Message.Msg: New ruling: MBS trustees not subject to Trust Indenture Act 6/4/2013 COMMENTS (0) In one of the myriad pretrial motions New York State Supreme Court Justice Barbara Kapnick heard Monday before opening arguments on Bank of America's proposed $8.5 billion settlement with investors in Countrywide mortgage-backed securities, objectors' counsel Beth Kaswan of Scott + Scott told the judge that Countrywide MBS trustee Bank of New York Mellon pushed to settle breach of contract claims because it was afraid of its own liability for failing to protect certificate holders. "The trustee is equally exposed to liability," she said. "The trustee had a very significant interest in resolving these claims quietly." Kaswan was referring to a pair of class action rulings her firm has won from two New York federal judges, U.S. District Judge William Pauley and U.S. District Judge Katherine Forrest, finding that MBS trustees are subject to liability to investors under the Trust Indenture Act. As I've told you, Pauley - the first judge to consider the issue - determined that mortgage-backed securities are debt, not equity, so the TIA applies to the trustees who oversee MBS trusts. Judge Forrest agreed with Pauley, then subsequently rejected trustee arguments that even if mortgage-backed securities are equity, they're exempt from the TIA under an exception for notes that "represent an interest or participation in two or more securities that have substantially different rights and privileges." Last month, the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals granted interlocutory review of Pauley's ruling, though Forrest declined to certify hers for a midcase review. As Kaswan was speaking before Kapnick Monday, a third federal judge in New York weighed in on the potential liability of MBS trustees in another Scott + Scott case. But unlike Pauley and Forrest, U.S. District Judge John Koeltl found that the Trust Indenture Act does not apply to MBS certificates. Koeltl concluded that the TIA's exemption for notes based on an interest in multiple securities applies to MBS certificates because they're based on mortgage notes with "different obligors, payment terms, maturity dates, interest rates and collateral." Moreover, he said, the underlying mortgages "originate in different states and are subject to different laws regarding foreclosure procedures and deficiency judgments." Koeltl said he did not even have to reach the question of whether mortgage-backed securities are debt or equity. The judge based his decision on three factors: the plain language of the TIA exemption, the longstanding interpretation of the statute by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the reliance of the trustee, U.S. Bank, and the MBS sponsor, Bear Stearns, on the SEC interpretation in structuring the transaction. Koeltl cited SEC guidance documents and no-action letters explaining that MBS certificates don't qualify as indentures under the TIA because mortgage pools consist of multiple notes with varying terms, and said that he owes deference to the SEC's analysis, which he said was also supported by legislative history. Koeltl pointed out that Bear Stearns and U.S. Bank structured some of the mortgage-backed offerings at issue in the case as notes subject to the TIA, with indenture documents that refer specifically to the statute. But the pooling and servicing agreement governing the MBS certificates made no mention of the TIA and were structured to take advantage of the law's exemption. "Having structured a transaction within (an) exemption of the TIA, supported by a plain reading of that exemption and long-standing SEC guidance," the judge wrote, "the TIA should not now be retroactively applied to the certificates." Scott + Scott's Kaswan told me Tuesday morning that Koeltl's ruling doesn't acknowledge that certificate holders don't have an interest in individual underlying mortgages but in the pool as a whole, which is subject to one set of terms. Investors have also argued that mortgages aren't securities as they're defined by the TIA exemption. As a matter of policy, Kaswan said, MBS investors should be able to rely on the TIA to assure that trustees are held accountable. In any event, she said she expects the 2nd Circuit will take a broad look at whether MBS certificates are subject to the TIA when the appellate court hears BNY Mellon's appeal, even though the Pauley ruling in the appeal addressed only the debt-versus-equity question. U.S. Bank was represented by Morgan, Lewis & Bockius. Lead counsel Michael Kraut referred me to the bank for comment but a representative was not immediately available. (Reporting by Alison Frankel)
